body:
I agree completely with your comment. That is my goal as well.

The wordcount execution _is_ definitely the cause of many spurious failures, with the error that the `WordCount` class cannot be found. I had hastily assumed this had something to do with staging files in a flaky manner, but if it is a local-only script, then the problem is just a bug in the script.

Perhaps it is interacting incorrectly with the `mvn` built artifacts. I'll close this PR and if I have a moment will take a look at why the script fails so often.
The needed changes to the Dataflow service are deployed.
Instead, choose #1180
Jenkins got killed in the middle of testing this; rebasing to kick.

> The wordcount execution is definitely the cause of many spurious failures, with the error that the WordCount class cannot be found.

I would be interested to see logs where the Maven verify/install of the SDK succeeded but wordcount flaked. My understanding is the wordcount flaking usually means the actual SDK install failed.
Example failure: https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/170276418/log.txt
Seems here that you _are_ reusing `ApiSurface` across modules, no?

If you want to use the list of modules that are on the SDK's surface, seems something like this would do it:

```
public class SdkApiSurface {
  public List<String> publicPackagesOnApiSurface = ...
}
```

It used to be that we needed more complex rules than just packages to manage the surface, but now I think it is just that simple.

Some desiderata for reuse:
- test automatically infers the module on which it should seed the API search.
- only 2 things in the file -- a whitelist and a ~1-line test that passes the whitelist as a parameter to some helper.
- test fails if there are things in the whitelist that are not exposed.

(other cool things that Maven enforcer does?)
R: @swegner
Those all sound like good starter JIRAs.
Next time I see it, I'll file a JIRA.
@dhalperi I ended up using 0.3.0-SNAPSHOT-DATE commit to absorb Flink 1.1.2
Jenkins failed on Dataflow streaming IT test - unrelated.

Why is `ExecutableTrigger` not yet removed and why is `Trigger.getWatermarkThatGuaranteesFiring()` still in `Trigger`?

Other than that, this LGTM! (I'm hoping that travis will not fail anymore once you merge... ðŸ˜ƒ)

@dhalperi This PR was opened against the `release-0.2.0-incubating` branch to bump the Flink version in a minor release. That would change the major version of Flink in a minor release of Beam. We quickly discussed this on the mailing list and figured it would be too much for a minor release.

@sumitchawla Thanks for your understanding. Could you close the PR?

Thanks for the review, I added all your suggestions.
I hope it is ok now.

Thanks for doing this cleanup. Can you add `org.apache.avro.reflect.Nullable` to the [Checkstyle IllegalImport](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/checkstyle.xml#L110) list?
This was not merged to the python-sdk branch, reopening it.

@kennknowles yep, for this metrics need to be supported. I would also like to use that to finish tests faster when all PAsserts were met, instead of waiting for the embedded cluster to shut down by itself.

Do you see anything else that needs to be done for this PR or can it be merged?

Yes, this LGTM. It is a step in the right direction. I am surprised that aggregators are not covered by `RunnableOnService` tests. But it is just as well, since I think the new metrics should totally replace them.

The reason I left `ExecutableTrigger` is because of `WindowingStrategy.getTrigger()`. We only really ever need `WindowingStrategy.getTrigger().getSpec()` but eliminating the extra level of indirection is yet another migration step.

And I left `getWatermarkThatGuaranteesFiring()` because it is actually a property of the abstract trigger, not especially a property of the state machine, just like `continuationTrigger`.

So I'm hoping my answer is enough to satisfy your prerequisites for LGTM. I will merge this, and definitely will be following up with eliminating `ExecutableTrigger`. The discussion of what methods to finally leave on `Trigger` can be ongoing.

Avro's `@Nullable` is valuable part of describing objects with `@DefaultCoder(AvroCoder.class)`. Have to live with this one.

E.g.: 

https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/b5e15c23a97a36b6e159610ad6ea7cd92a6c8c3e/examples/java8/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/examples/complete/game/UserScore.java#L81
And now it's in the official apache branch.
Thank you!
@dhalperi the Travis failures here are the ones mentioned where `WordCount` class cannot be found. Is there something in this change that you think triggers it?

R: Any committer. Probably most familiar/relevant to one of (@davorbonaci @dhalperi @lukecwik @jbonofre)

It is hard for me to tell from the state of the repo whether or not this worked. There is no attempt to download 0.4.0 snapshots, which there used to be, but I cannot tell if that is just because it is failing earlier :-/

OK, this is forward progress. I agree that the Jenkins signal does not apply to this PR.

So LGTM, with misgivings about our level of testing signal :-/
I'll relate to the comments and handle #1171 before merging so Jenkins will have another chance (or two) ðŸ˜‰

Bummer.  A quick search over Beam shows it's also being misused in `ApproximatelyUnique`-- want to replace that usage as well?

LGTM

Thanks Luke! I'll relate to your comments and decide what to do with the `kryo-serializers` version.
R: @lukecwik
OK, this is ready for review. I have removed all non-essential uses of `OldDoFn` from `beam-runners-direct-java`.

I think this one should be a job property, as in some ideal eventual world,
it will be the identity used for all parts of the job.

@robertwb can you take a look?
This fix was just rebased over quite a few commits - fixing it up.
The only essential use is `GroupAlsoByWindowEvaluatorFactory`, yes?
Perfect, I was just interested in how you might proceed there. ðŸ‘

@lukecwik I've replied to specific comments.
Generally this is not a user-facing feature, but an internal feature that was meant to help with Source API support.
For the data in the pipeline, I'm generally using coders, but Sources don't have them so I can't use coders.
As for the `kryo-serializers` version - since Spark's [KryoSerializer](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/branch-1.6/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/serializer/KryoSerializer.scala) pre-registers some classes and I only use those additional-specific `Serializers`; it either works or it doesn't, which is also what the author of this library told me (I contributed `ReverseListSerializer` so I asked him).
WDYT ?
Great. Merging.
That is correct. There is exactly one use.

The Travis failures appear to all be when running `ViewTest`, not related to this PR. Since on `master` Travis gives sketchy signal, I may have been too hasty in ignoring it on the previous Apex PR. It may also be that running embedded Apex with those side input tests hits memory limits of Travis's container infrastructure. @tweise what do you think?
Haven't had much luck with integration tests and Travis yet (usually hits timeout). Only Jenkins gives reliable signals. I'm going to run the tests with the rebased PR locally.

That makes sense to me with respect to the usage of KryoSerializer that you want to make it hidden. Advanced users that specify the Spark context on PipelineOptions will need to know that they need to also set the same properties as is being set here.

2 out of 5 travis passed.
PTAL

As I see it, there are two ways to go here:
1. A provided context is responsible to provide the proper configurations for `spark.kryo.registrator` and `spark.serializer` (and anything else the runner may require in the future).
2. The runner forces an override of the mentioned configurations for any provided context - safer for runner use, but changes user defined context quietly.
I prefer an explicit failure over a pipeline that executes different then the author intended (currently, if missing those two configurations the pipeline will fail anyway..).
Thoughts ?
I just fixed the license issue. This time should be ok (modulo the IT issues).
Ended up using 0.3.0-SNAPSHOT-DATE commit to absorb Flink 1.1.2
I agree with your points and believe that we should go with 1.
OK, thanks for the explanation. Then everything LGTM.

I think now you are hitting timeouts just because the tests take so long to run. There have been some recent discussions of how to balance pre vs postcommit tests, etc, on the dev list. The precommit here is really what all the other runners have in postcommit, but for the feature branch it makes sense to focus on it. You could speed things up by locally forking the pom to disable other runner test suites, if you are feeling bold. I know the Python SDK disables Java tests to make Travis fast.

Yes, they take pretty long and it will be future work to make them run faster. Please also see my question on the list, should the integration tests be enabled by default (they are not for the other runners)?
R: @kennknowles
LGTM. Weird.

integration tests pass locally
LGTM
R: @dhalperi
+R: @jasonkuster
@eljefe6a , @robertwb , @dhalperi , any thoughts after the discussion?
Noting that the Jenkins failures are exactly those that are expected.

Since eventually they will be a postcommit, and they are not giving a signal now, it seems like a good time to disable them except when `-Plocal-runnable-on-service-tests` is provided.

They served their purpose during development pretty well and now the runner is sort of in the next stage of life :-). We can use gists to share logs of failed local runs to serve the purpose that the Jenkins logs did during the initial development, if it comes to that.
Not sure why this conflict occurs. Seems to be running and building fine. Not sure what I am missing.
@lukecwik is this LGTM then ?
R: @kennknowles
On your branch, can you run `git rebase origin/master`? After this, you'll need to `git push -f nssalian BEAM-651-new` (assuming you have your fork set up to be called `nssalian`)
I'll merge this now and when streaming supports the model properly, I'll use `GroupAlsoByWindowViaWindowSet` where necessary, for now this is a good step forward.

One more note for provided context - it's interesting to see how using this will unfold.. it opens up the possibility of working with [spark-jobserver](https://github.com/spark-jobserver/spark-jobserver) and (once Scio is stable enough I guess) working with Spark's REPL.
I assume I'll introduce some changes according to issues that may arise from those use-cases, but I'm trying to not get ahead of myself and simply see what's needed once it's needed.
@kennknowles @dhalperi Sorry this merge is huge. I will try my best to sync as frequent as possible from now on.

Code changes LGTM! ðŸ‘ 

By the way, I like this strategy of doing PRs/commits for all the little steps of a big refactoring. In Flink we tend to do changes in huge monolithic commits/PRs. This sometimes makes it hard to review them and people tend to wait a long time before reviewing.
Aggregators are now reported using the following hierarchical path: "`spark`.`[appId]`.`driver`.`[appName]`.`Beam`.`[aggregatorName]`"
Added some minor comments, ping me once ready and I'll merge. Thanks!
Let me know how it looks.
LGTM, I'll merge once Jenkins passes.
LGTM

Merged, thanks!
